Finding My Creative Voice Through Motion Design
How experimenting with timing, rhythm and movement helped shape my creative identity.

## Finding My Creative Voice Through Motion Design

Motion design has always fascinated me — the idea that simple shapes, photos or illustrations can come alive with timing and rhythm feels almost magical. When I created my first animation, I realised how much control motion gives you over atmosphere, storytelling and emotion.

What I enjoy most is experimenting. A transition might start as a mistake, a texture might come from a completely unrelated photo, and an animation curve might change the entire mood of a scene. Motion design is where creativity meets problem-solving, and that combination keeps me inspired every day.

This project taught me not to fear the blank canvas. Animation isn’t about perfection — it’s about exploring movement, refining details and slowly discovering your own visual language.

Behind the Scenes: Building a Portfolio That Feels Like Me
A look at the creative decisions behind my website design.

## Behind the Scenes: Building a Portfolio That Feels Like “Me”

Creating a portfolio is more than collecting your work — it’s deciding how you want people to see you. For a long time, I struggled with that. Should it be minimal? Bold? Playful? Professional?

Eventually, I realised the answer was simple: it should feel like me.

I started by looking at the techniques I enjoy most: motion design, photography, visual storytelling. Then I built the layout around those strengths. The big typography, the black-and-white contrast, the energetic hints of color — all of it reflects how I approach creativity.

A portfolio will always grow and evolve, but this version feels honest. It shows not only what I can make, but how I think. And that is the part I’m most proud of.

Behind the Scenes: Building a Portfolio That Feels Like “Me”
Why Every Creative Should Learn 3D (Even Just a Little)
3D opens new creative possibilities — even for beginners.

## Why Every Creative Should Learn 3D (Even Just a Little)

3D can feel intimidating at first: too many buttons, too many views, too many ways to break something. But once I took my first steps into Blender, I realised how powerful even the simplest techniques can be.

Learning 3D expands the way you think. Suddenly, lighting becomes a storytelling tool. Materials behave like real objects. And you’re no longer limited by what a camera can capture — you can create anything you imagine.

You don’t need to master sculpting or complex simulations. Even basic shapes, simple animations or stylised renders can elevate a project. For designers, filmmakers and creatives of any kind, 3D is no longer optional — it’s an exciting playground filled with possibilities.
